article:
In United States patent law, a 'method', also called "process", is one of the
four principal categories of things that may be patented through "utility
patents". The other three are a machine, an article of manufacture (also termed
a manufacture), and a composition of matter.

In that context, a method is a process, or series of steps or acts, for
performing a function or accomplishing a result. See Gottschalk v. Benson,
409 U.S. 63, 70 (1972) (âA process is a mode of treatment of certain materials
to produce a given result. It is an act, or a series of acts, performed upon the
subject-matter to be transformed and reduced to a different state or thing.â).
See also In re Kollar, 286 F.3d 1326, 1332 (Fed. Cir. 2002) (â[A]
process...consists of a series of acts or steps.... It consists of doing
something, and therefore has to be carried out or performed.â). The terms
are largely interchangeable, Thus section 100(b) of the US patent act, 35
U.S.C. sec. 100(b), states, "The term 'process' means process, art, or method,
and includes a new use of a known process...." but "process" usually
refers to a manufacturing processâa series of steps for making something, while
a "method" usually refers to a way of using a product to accomplish a given
result. Thus, one might speak of a process for making soap or candles, or speak
of a method for curing headaches comprising administering a therapeutically
effective dosage of aspirin.

Not all methods, in the dictionary sense, are methods for purposes of United
States patent law. The case law "forecloses a purely literal reading of Â§
101." Parker v. Flook, 437 U.S. 584, 589 (1978). In Gottschalk v. Benson,
409 U.S. 63, 64 (1973), the Court said, "The question is whether the method
described and claimed is a 'process' within the meaning of the Patent Act." See
also In re Bilski ("But the Supreme Court has held that the meaning of 'process'
as used in Â§ 101 is narrower than its ordinary meaning."). The concept is
elaborated in the article Machine-or-transformation test.

Previously, a method patent claim could be infringed only when a single person
or entity practices all claimed steps. "[A] method claim is only infringed
when a single party can be charged with performing each step of the asserted
claim." Muniauction v. Thomson Corp. and i-Deal, (Fed. Cir. 2008) [http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov/opinions/07-
1485.pdf opinion] Neither a physical device, such as a product that can be
used to practice the method, nor instructions for practicing the method, are
infringing until they are used by a single person to perform all the steps
together. This rule was changed in Akamai Tech. v. Limelight Networks (Fed. Cir.
2012).  Akamai Tech. v. Limelight Networks (Fed. Cir. 2012) [http://http://www.ipwatchdog.com/2012/09/04/cafcs-joint-infringement-
conundrum-p1/id=27774/ ipwatchdog review of decision]
